2040/A0/05/902/001.status_value: 6 states formed a Nutrition Mission to improve multi-sectoral coordination for nutrition. All 13 states have plans and budgets to scale up maternal and infant and young child nutrition interventions. UNICEF augments the technical capacity of National Health Mission and Integrated Child Development Services programme and scales up these interventions with equity and quality.
2040/A0/05/902/001.indicator_name: Proportion of states with a comprehensive (Comprehensive means that it prioritizes the delivery of all evidence-based  essential nutrition interventions through a mix of facility-  outreach- and community-based approaches  with a commensurate budget) programme implementation plan and budgets to scale up services to protect  promote and support optimal infant and young child feeding practices and related maternal nutrition

2040/A0/05/901/003.status_value: 67 per cent of delivery points in UNICEF supported HPDs have staff trained in SBA and neonatal resuscitation. 2040/A0/05/901/003.status_value: 90 percent: The progress is good with 90% of UNICEF supported high priority districts having a functional FRU in place. UNICEF support for FRU focused on leveraging budgets under district and state plans  planning for required Human Resources  equipment and services based on norms as per the MNH tool kit developed with support of UNICEF and other partners. In the districts where FRUs were already functional focus has been on supportive supervision and quality assurance based on gap analysis find

2040/A0/05/903/005.status_value: To date  67% (323 out of 481) districts are implementing policies to reduce open defecation. Programme success is being achieved through a multipronged approach of which district level planning and implementation is the fulcrum. UNICEF supported this approach in 15 states and over 100 districts of the country.
